Great Wisdom!
There are four kinds of characteristics of verbal distinctions,

Great Wisdom!
The characteristics of verbal distinctions refer to the attachment to one's own discriminated characteristics of form.
As for dream-talk, it refers to remembering past experiences upon waking up, arising based on unreal objects.
As for talk of past offenses, it refers to recollecting past actions of enmity.
As for talk of beginningless delusion, it arises from the habitual tendencies of beginningless frivolous discourse and deluded attachment.
These are the four.
Mahamati further said:

Where do they come from?
What are their causes?
How do they arise?
The Buddha said:
Mahamati!
They arise from the combination of the head, chest, throat, nose, lips, palate, teeth, and tongue.
Mahamati further said:
World-Honored One!
Are verbal distinctions different or not different?
The Buddha said:
Mahamati!
They are neither different nor not different.
Why is it so?

Because discrimination arises as the cause for the production of language. If they were different, discrimination would not be the cause. If they were not different, language would not manifest meaning. Therefore, they are neither different nor not different.

The ultimate truth is the realm of the inner realization of the wisdom of the sages, not the realm of discrimination by language and thought. Language and thought cannot reveal it.

Language arises and ceases, moves and shakes, and is produced by a series of causes and conditions. If it is produced by a series of causes and conditions, it cannot reveal the ultimate truth.

One should be far removed from verbal discrimination.

If it is because of clinging to various illusory appearances that it is said that all dharmas are like illusions, World-Honored One!

Why is it so?
Because various forms are seen not to be without causes.
World-Honored One!
There are no causes at all that make various forms appear like illusions.
Therefore, World-Honored One!
It cannot be said that it relies on the various illusory appearances that are clung to, and that all dharmas are similar to illusions.
The Buddha said:
Great Wisdom!
It does not rely on the various illusory appearances that are clung to, and says that all dharmas are like illusions.
Great Wisdom!
Because all dharmas are unreal and quickly perish like lightning, it is said to be like an illusion.
Great Wisdom!

It is like a flash of lightning that is seen and then disappears. The foolish in the world all clearly see all dharmas, which appear based on their own discriminations of specific and general characteristics, in the same way. Because they are unable to contemplate the non-existent, they falsely cling to various forms and appearances.
At that time the World-Honored One spoke a verse, saying:
Without illusion there is no similarity, and also there are not various dharmas;
Unreal and quickly passing like lightning, like an illusion one should know.
At that time the Bodhisattva MahÄsattva Great Wisdom again addressed the Buddha, saying:
World-Honored One!
As the Buddha has previously said, all dharmas are completely unborn;
and also said to be like an illusion, is it not contradictory to say these things?
The Buddha said:
Great Wisdom!
There is no contradiction.
Why is this?
I have realized that birth is precisely non-birth, because it is only seen by one's own mind.
Whether existent or non-existent, all external dharmas are seen to be without nature and originally unborn.
Great Wisdom!
In order to avoid the meaning of birth from causes propounded by non-Buddhists, I say that all dharmas are completely unborn.
Great Wisdom!
Non-Buddhists gather together and give rise to evil views, saying that all dharmas are born from existence and non-existence, not taking their own attachments and discrimination as conditions.
Great Wisdom!
I say that all dharmas are not born from existence or non-existence, therefore they are called unborn.
Great Wisdom!
The teaching of all dharmas is to cause disciples to know that they accept birth and death based on their own karma, in order to prevent them from having the view of annihilation.
Great Wisdom!
Speaking of the characteristics of all dharmas as being like illusions is to cause one to be free from the characteristics of the intrinsic natures of all dharmas.

For the sake of those foolish ordinary beings who fall into evil views and desires, not knowing that all dharmas are only manifestations of the mind, in order to cause them to be free from grasping and attachment to the characteristics of arising from causes and conditions, it is said that all dharmas are like illusions and like dreams.
Those foolish beings, attached to evil views and deceiving themselves and others, are unable to clearly see the suchness of all dharmas as they really are.
Great Wisdom!
Seeing the suchness of all dharmas means being able to understand that they are only manifestations of the mind.
At that time the World Honored One spoke a verse, saying:
Because there is no creation, there is no arising; the existent dharma subsumes birth and death;
Understanding it to be like an illusion and so forth, one does not discriminate characteristics.
Furthermore, Great Wisdom!

I will now explain the characteristics of name, phrase, and syllable groups. Bodhisattva-mahÄsattvas who skillfully contemplate these characteristics and understand their meaning will quickly attain supreme perfect enlightenment and be able to awaken all sentient beings.
Great Wisdom!
Name group means establishing a name based on an event. The name itself is the body, so it is called the name group.
Phrase group means that which can reveal the meaning and bring it to completion. This is called the phrase group.
Syllable group means that which can form names and phrases. This is called the syllable group.
Furthermore, Great Wisdom!
Phrase group means the completion of the matter of a phrase.
Name group means the individual differences of various letters and names, such as from the letter A up to the letter Ka.
Syllable group means long, short, high, and low.
Furthermore, phrase group is like a footprint, like the footprints of people and animals in a street.
Name refers to the four aggregates of non-form, because they are spoken of by name.
Words refer to the intrinsic characteristics of names, because they manifest through words.
These are called the aggregates of names, phrases, and syllables.
You should cultivate and study the characteristics of these names, phrases, and syllables.
At that time the World-Honored One spoke a verse, saying:
The aggregates of names, phrases, and syllables are distinguished;
The foolish and ignorant cling to them, like an elephant sinking in deep mud.
Furthermore, Mahamati!
In the future there will be those with false wisdom and evil thoughts who, apart from the true Dharma, will ask the wise about the characteristics of sameness, difference, both, and neither.
They will immediately reply, 'This is not a proper question.'
Namely:
Is form different from impermanence, or not different?

In this way, nirvana and conditioned phenomena, characteristics and the characterized, basis and what is based, product and producer, seer and what is seen, earth and dust, wisdom and the wise, are they different or not different?
If one asks about such matters that cannot be answered, the World-Honored One explains this as a matter to be set aside and answered.
Foolish people are ignorant and unable to understand. The Buddha wishes to cause them to leave the place of fear and does not explain it for them.
Great Wisdom!
Not explaining it is in order to cause non-Buddhists to forever leave the view of an agent.
Great Wisdom!
The various non-Buddhist groups reckon there is an agent and speak like this:
'Life is the body, life is different from the body, different from the body.'
Such explanations are called indeterminate theories.
Great Wisdom!

Non-Buddhists foolishly and confusedly explain indeterminate theories. In my teachings, it is explained as leaving the grasper and the grasped, not giving rise to discrimination. How can it be stopped?
Great Wisdom!
If there is attachment to the grasper and the grasped, not understanding that it is only what is seen by one's own mind, then it can be stopped.
Great Wisdom!
The buddhas and tathÄgatas use the four kinds of indeterminate theories to explain the Dharma for sentient beings.
Great Wisdom!
I will explain the treatise on cessation at another time, because the faculties of sentient beings are not yet mature and I will temporarily stop explaining it.
Furthermore, Mahamati!
Why are all dharmas unborn?
Because they are free from the doer and the deed, and there is no doer.
Why are all dharmas without self-nature?
Because in the observation of verifying cognition, the specific and general characteristics cannot be obtained.
Why are all dharmas without coming and going?
Because the specific and general characteristics come from nowhere and go nowhere.
Why are all dharmas not extinguished?
Because all dharmas are without nature and characteristics, and cannot be obtained.
Why are all dharmas impermanent?
Because the arising of various characteristics is impermanent by nature.
Why are all dharmas permanent?
Because the arising of various characteristics is precisely non-arising, because of non-existence.
The nature of impermanence is permanent, therefore I say all dharmas are permanent.
At that time the World Honored One spoke a verse, saying:
Direct, counter-questioning, analytical, and setting aside;
Thus there are four kinds of explanations, which subdue all non-Buddhists.
SÄá¹ƒkhya and VaiÅ›eá¹£ika say there is production from existence and non-existence;
Such statements are all indeterminate.
When examined with wisdom, their essence cannot be found;
Since they are indescribable, they are said to be natureless.
At that time, the Bodhisattva MahÄsattva Great Wisdom again addressed the Buddha, saying:
World-Honored One!

Please explain to me the characteristics of the practices of all stream-enterers and the fruits of stream-entry. I and all bodhisattva-mahÄsattvas, having heard this meaning, will attain skillfulness in the characteristics of the skillful means of stream-enterers, once-returners, non-returners, and arhats.

Thus, for the sake of sentient beings, he expounds in this way, enabling them to realize the Dharma of the two kinds of no-self and purify the two hindrances. Gradually penetrating the characteristics of the stages, they attain the inconceivable wisdom realm of the TathÄgata, like a multicolored maá¹‡i jewel, universally enabling all sentient beings to obtain benefit.
The Buddha said:
Listen carefully!
I will explain it for you.
MahÄmati said:
Yes.
The Buddha said:
MahÄmati!
There are three distinctions among srotÄpannas and srotÄpatti fruits, namely:
inferior, middling, and superior.
MahÄmati!
The inferior one is reborn in the various existences up to seven times, the middling one is reborn three or five times, and the superior one enters nirvÄá¹‡a in this very life.
MahÄmati!
These three kinds of people sever the three kinds of bonds, namely:
belief in the self, doubt, and adherence to rules and rituals. Progressively advancing to the highest, they attain the fruit of arhatship.
MahÄmati!
The view of a real self is of two kinds, namely innate and discriminating, like the false nature that arises based on dependent origination.
Great Wisdom!

It is like how, based on the nature of dependent origination, the nature of various false attachments arises. Those dharmas are merely the characteristics of false discrimination, neither existent nor nonexistent, neither existent nor nonexistent. Foolish ordinary beings falsely cling to them, like a thirsty animal mistakenly giving rise to the thought of water. This discriminating view of a real self is due to the lack of wisdom. It has been associated with [beings] for a long time. If one sees the non-self of persons, one will immediately abandon it.
Great Wisdom!

The innate view of a real self is to thoroughly observe one's own and others' bodies, and the four skandhas of feeling, etc., because they have no form. Form arises due to the great elements. Those great elements mutually cause each other. Form is not accumulated. Having observed in this way, one clearly sees existence and non-existence and immediately abandons it.
Because one abandons the view of a real self, craving does not arise. This is called the characteristic of the view of a real self.
Great Wisdom!

The characteristic of doubt is that because one well sees the characteristics of the realized Dharma, and because the two kinds of views of self are eliminated, doubt cannot arise regarding any dharmas. One also does not give rise to the notion of a great teacher as pure or impure elsewhere. This is called the characteristic of doubt.
Great Wisdom!
Why do SrotÄpannas not grasp at precepts and observances?
It is because they clearly see the characteristics of suffering in the places of rebirth that they do not grasp at them.

As for those who grasp at them, it is because foolish common people, within the various existences, crave for worldly pleasures, and through ascetic practices and upholding precepts, wish to be reborn there. SrotÄpannas do not grasp at these characteristics, but only seek the most supreme undefiled and non-discriminating Dharma that they have realized, and cultivate the category of precepts. Because SrotÄpannas abandon the three bonds, they are free from greed, hatred, and delusion.

There are many kinds of greed. Which greed is abandoned?
The Buddha said:
Great Wisdom!

Abandoning attachment to female form and clinging to desire, seeing that present happiness leads to future suffering, and attaining the supreme bliss of samÄdhi, therefore abandoning attachment to that which is not nirvÄá¹‡a.

As for the arhat, it means fully accomplishing meditative concentrations, samÄdhis, liberations, powers, and spiritual penetrations, and completely ending discrimination of afflictions and sufferings, this is called the arhat.

World-Honored One!
There are three kinds of arhats, namely:
They are heading single-mindedly towards quiescence, turning away from the vow for enlightenment, and are transformations of the Buddha.

The Buddha said:
Great Wisdom!
This refers to those heading towards quiescence, not the others.
Great Wisdom!
There are two other kinds of people, namely:
Those who have already given rise to skillful means and vows, and those who adorn the assemblies of the Buddhas and manifest birth there.
Great Wisdom!

In the realm of delusion, various teachings are expounded, namely, the realization of fruition and meditation, because they are all inherently detached, and because one sees the marks of attaining fruition within one's own mind.
Great Wisdom!
If a stream-enterer has the thought:
'I am free from the bonds,'
then there are two faults, namely:
Falling into the view of self and not severing the bonds.
Furthermore, Great Wisdom!
If one wishes to transcend the meditations, the formless realm of immeasurable [concentrations], one should be free from the various marks seen in one's own mind.
Great Wisdom!
The samÄdhi of the cessation of conceptualization and sensation that transcends the objects seen by one's own mind is not so, because it is not apart from the mind.
At that time the World-Honored One spoke a verse, saying:ğŸ”½The various dhyÄnas, immeasurables,

There are two kinds of enlightened wisdom, namely:

The wisdom of observation means observing all dharmas, free from the four propositions and unobtainable.
The four propositions are:
identity, difference, both, neither, existence, non-existence, permanence, impermanence, and so forth.
I say that all dharmas are free from the four propositions because they are free from these.
Great Wisdom!
You should cultivate and study in this way to observe dharmas.
What is the knowledge of grasping characteristics, discriminating, and attachedly establishing?

It refers to grasping characteristics, being attached, and falsely discriminating the natures of the great elements such as solidity, moisture, heat, and movement, and falsely establishing them with tenets, reasons, and examples. This is called the knowledge of grasping characteristics, discriminating, and attachedly establishing.
These are called the two kinds of characteristics of awakened knowledge.

Bodhisattva-mahÄsattvas who understand this characteristic of cognition can immediately penetrate the non-self of persons and dharmas. With cognition of the absence of characteristics, they skillfully observe on the ground of resolve and practice, enter the first ground, attain a hundred samÄdhis, and with the power of supreme samÄdhi see a hundred Buddhas and a hundred bodhisattvas, understand events of a hundred eons in the past and future, illuminate a hundred Buddha-lands with light, well understand the characteristics of the higher and higher grounds, with the power of supreme vows manifest transformations at will, reach the cloud of Dharma ground and receive the consecration, enter the Buddha ground, with ten inexhaustible vows accomplish sentient beings, and manifest various forms without rest, while always abiding in the supreme bliss of samÄdhi in the realm of self-realization.
Furthermore, Mahamati!
Bodhisattva-mahÄsattvas should thoroughly understand the great elements and derivative form.
How should they understand?

Bodhisattva-mahÄsattvas should contemplate in this way: those great elements are truly unborn, because the three realms are merely conceptualization, only the mind's manifestations, with no external objects.

When contemplating in this way, the great elements and their derivatives are all essentially devoid, transcending the four propositions, with no self or possessions, abiding in the place of suchness, accomplishing the characteristic of non-arising.
MaheÅ›vara!
How do those great elements form derivative form?
MaheÅ›vara!

It means that the great element of moisture forms the internal and external water element through false discrimination, the great element of heat forms the internal and external fire element, the great element of motion forms the internal and external wind element, and the great element of form and segments forms the internal and external earth element, apart from space. Due to attachment to false truths, the great elements and derivative form arise from the aggregation of the five aggregates.
MaheÅ›vara!
Consciousness arises due to attachment to various verbalized objects as causes, and continues to experience birth in other destinies.
MaheÅ›vara!ğŸ”½Here is the corrected and aligned text:
Earth and other derivative forms have the cause of the great elements, but the four great elements are not the cause of the great elements.
Why is this?
If there is a dharma with form and characteristics, then it is created, not that which is without form.

This characteristic of the great elements and derivative forms is the discrimination of non-Buddhists, not what I teach.
Furthermore, MaheÅ›vara!
I will now explain the essence and characteristics of the five aggregates, namely:
form, feeling, perception, mental formations, and consciousness.
MaheÅ›vara!
Form refers to the four great elements and the derivative forms, each with different characteristics.
Feeling and so forth are not form.
MaheÅ›vara!
The aggregates that are not form are like empty space, without the four numbers.
MaheÅ›vara!

It is like empty space, surpassing the characteristics of numbers, yet one discriminates and says this is empty space. The aggregates that are not form are also like this, apart from the characteristics of all numbers, apart from the four phrases such as existence and non-existence.

As for the characteristics of number, they are spoken of by foolish people, not by the sages. The sages only say that they are like illusions, only provisionally established, neither the same nor different, like dreams and reflections, with nothing separate from them.

Because they do not understand the realm of the wisdom of the sages, they see the various aggregates appearing due to discrimination. This is called the intrinsic nature characteristic of the aggregates.
Great Wisdom!

You should abandon such discrimination. Having abandoned it, you will speak the Dharma of tranquility, cut off the views of all the non-Buddhists in the various lands, purify the Dharma of no-self, enter the far-reaching ground, accomplish immeasurable freely-roaming samÄdhis, attain the body born of the mind, and be fully endowed with the powers and spiritual penetrations of the samÄdhi of illusion, just like the great earth universally benefiting all beings.

There are four kinds of nirvÄá¹‡a.
What are the four?

These four nirvÄá¹‡as are the meaning of the non-Buddhists, not what I teach.
Great Wisdom!
What I teach is that the cessation of the consciousness of discrimination and appearances is called nirvÄá¹‡a.
Great Wisdom said:
World-Honored One!
Aren't the eight kinds of consciousness established?
The Buddha said:
They are established.
Great Wisdom said:
If they are established, why only speak of the cessation of the mental consciousness and not the cessation of the seven consciousnesses?
The Buddha said:
Great Wisdom!
Because they are the cause and the object, the seven consciousnesses can arise.
Great Wisdom!

When the discriminating consciousness discriminates objects and gives rise to attachment, it produces habitual tendencies and nourishes the store consciousness. Thus, the mind-associated self and self-grasping thoughts revolve without a separate essence or characteristics. The store consciousness serves as the cause and object, and thus one clings to the objects manifested by one's own mind. The assembly of mind arises and evolves as causes for each other.
Great Wisdom!

It is like the waves of the ocean, manifested by one's own mind, blown by the wind of objects and thus arising and ceasing. Therefore, when the discriminating consciousness ceases, the seven consciousnesses also cease.
At that time the World Honored One spoke a verse, saying:ğŸ”½I do not speak of nirvana as the essence,
Or as the cessation of the discrimination of objects and consciousness,ğŸ”½The discriminating consciousness is the cause of the mind,
And the mind is the object of the discriminating consciousness;
Because of cause and object, the consciousnesses arise based on it.
Just as when a great torrent ends, waves do not arise,
In this way, when mental consciousness ceases, various consciousnesses do not arise.
Furthermore, Mahamati!

I will now explain the characteristics of the distinctions of the nature of false imagination, enabling you and all Bodhisattva-Mahasattvas to understand this meaning well, transcend all false imaginations, realize the realm of holy wisdom, know the teachings of non-Buddhists, and be free from the discriminations of grasper and grasped. Within the various characteristics of dependent arising, do not grasp at the characteristics imagined by false imagination again.
Mahamati!
What are the characteristics of the distinctions of the nature of false imagination?
They are:

Speech discrimination, spoken discrimination, characteristic discrimination, wealth discrimination, self-nature discrimination, cause discrimination, view discrimination, principle discrimination, arising discrimination, non-arising discrimination, related discrimination, and bondage-liberation discrimination.
Mahamati!
These are the characteristics of the distinctions of the nature of false imagination.
What is speech discrimination?
It refers to the attachment to various beautiful and wonderful sounds and words, which is called the discrimination of speech.
What is the discrimination of what is spoken?

It refers to the attachment to the existence of what is spoken, which is the realm realized by the wisdom of the sages. Based on this, speech arises. This is called the discrimination of what is spoken.
What is the discrimination of characteristics?

It refers to the discrimination and attachment to all characteristics such as solidity, moisture, heat, and movement, like the thoughts of a thirsty animal, regarding those things that are spoken. This is called the discrimination of characteristics.
What is the discrimination of wealth?
It refers to the attachment to various gold, silver, and other treasures, and the arising of speech. This is called the discrimination of wealth.
What is the discrimination of self-nature?
It refers to the discrimination of this self-nature as definitely not being anything else, using evil views in this way. This is called the discrimination of self-nature.
What is the discrimination of causes?

It refers to the discrimination of the existence or non-existence of causes and conditions, because these characteristics of causes are able to give rise to [results]. This is called the discrimination of causes.
What is the discrimination of views?
Namely, the non-Buddhists, due to their evil views, cling to existence, non-existence, sameness, difference, both, and neither, etc. This is called the discrimination of views.
What is the discrimination of principles?
Namely, clinging to the characteristics of self and what belongs to self, and giving rise to speech. This is called the discrimination of principles.
What is the discrimination of arising?
Namely, considering that all dharmas, whether existent or non-existent, arise from conditions. This is called the discrimination of arising.

What is the discrimination of non-arising? Namely, considering that all dharmas have never arisen from the beginning, that before the conditions exist, there is already a substance, and that they do not arise from causes. This is called the discrimination of non-arising.
What is the discrimination of mutual dependence?
Namely, this and that mutually depend on each other, like a needle and thread. This is called the discrimination of mutual dependence.
What is the discrimination of bondage and liberation?

Namely, considering that the cause can bind and there is that which is bound, just as a person uses the power of a rope to bind and then unbind. This is called the discrimination of bondage and liberation.
MaheÅ›vara!
This is the characteristic of the difference in false imagination, which all foolish common people cling to as existent or nonexistent.
MaheÅ›vara!
In dependent origination, clinging to various false imaginations is like seeing various things based on an illusion. Foolish people see it as different from the illusion.
MaheÅ›vara!
Illusion and various things are neither different nor not different. If they were different, illusion would not be the cause of various things;
if they were the same, illusion and various things would have no distinction, but we see a distinction, therefore they are neither different nor not different.
MaheÅ›vara!
You and all bodhisattva-mahÄsattvas should not give rise to attachment to existence or nonexistence in illusions.

The mind is bound by objects, and conceptual cognition follows along;
In the signless supreme place, equal wisdom arises.
In false imagination it exists, but in dependent origination it is nonexistent;
Deludedly grasping at false imagination, dependent arising is free from discrimination.
Various branches arise, like illusions that are not accomplished;
Although various appearances manifest, false discrimination is non-existent.
Those appearances are precisely faults, all arising from the bondage of the mind;
Those who falsely imagine do not understand, discriminating the Dharma of dependent arising.
The nature of these false imaginations is precisely dependent arising;
False imagination has various kinds, discriminated within dependent arising.
The conventional, the ultimate truth, and the third [truth] arising without cause;
False imagination is conventional, cut off, then the realm of sages.
Like a practitioner in meditation, various [things] appear in one [thing];
In it there is no variety, false imagination's characteristics are like this.
Like various cataracts in the eyes, deluded thoughts see various colors;
They are neither colored nor non-colored, not understanding dependent arising.
Just as gold is free from dust and impurities, and water is free from mud and turbidity;
Just as the sky is free from clouds, the purification of conceptualization is like this.
There is no nature of false imagination, yet there is dependent origination;
Establishment and slander are due to the destruction of discrimination.
If there is no nature of false imagination, yet there is dependent origination;
There is no dharma yet there is dharma, existent dharma arises from nonexistence.
Dependent on false imagination, dependent origination can be obtained;
Signs and names always follow each other, and false imagination arises.
Because dependent origination relies on false imagination, it is ultimately not accomplished;
At that time, purity is manifested, and it is called the ultimate truth.

In the realm of the true suchness realized by oneself, there is no difference between them.
The five dharmas are true reality, and the three natures are also so;
Practitioners contemplate this, not going beyond true suchness.
Relying on the characteristics of dependent origination, falsely imagining various names;
Those falsely imagined characteristics all exist due to dependent origination.
Wisdom skillfully observes, without conditions, without false imagination;
In reality there are no things, so how can discrimination arise?
If the perfected [nature] exists, then it is apart from existence and non-existence;
Since it is already apart from existence and non-existence, how can there be two natures?
Falsely imagining there are two natures, the two natures are established;
Discrimination sees various [things], the pure realm of the sages.
Falsely imagining various characteristics, discriminating within dependent origination;
If different from this discrimination, then one falls into the treatises of non-Buddhists.
Because of various false views, falsely imagining within false imagination;
Those who are apart from these two imaginations, for them there is the true Dharma.
MahÄmati Bodhisattva-mahÄsattva again addressed the Buddha, saying:

This One Vehicle path is only for the TathÄgata, not for non-Buddhists, the Two Vehicles, or Brahma Heaven kings and so forth.
